timeline.label: New York Governor (1929-1932)
timeline.note: Labor reforms and unemployment relief programs signal emerging progressive economic approach.

timeline.label: Early Presidency (1933-1936)
timeline.note: New Deal programs expand public ownership and social support while maintaining strategic trade protections.

timeline.label: World War II Leadership (1937-1945)
timeline.note: War mobilization increases trade controls and state involvement, while civil liberties remain constrained.

timeline.label: California Governor (1967-1975)
timeline.note: Budget cuts and tax resistance begin the shift toward market-first economics and traditional rights framing.

timeline.label: Presidency (1981-1989)
timeline.note: Supply-side economics and deregulation dominate national policy; immigration reform expands quotas slightly.

timeline.label: Senate Career (2005-2008)
timeline.note: Support for free trade agreements balances with progressive rights expansion and immigration reforms.

timeline.label: First Term (2009-2012)
timeline.note: Affordable Care Act expands social programs while maintaining pro-trade stance and advancing LGBTQ rights.

timeline.label: Second Term (2013-2016)
timeline.note: DACA implementation and same-sex marriage support solidify progressive rights positions with market-friendly economics.

timeline.label: Business & Media Era (1980s-2015)
timeline.note: Public commentary favors strategic tariffs but not full trade wars; social positions align with conservative media.

timeline.label: First Presidency (2017-2021)
timeline.note: America First agenda brings heavy tariffs, strict immigration limits, and deregulation focus.

timeline.label: Second Presidency (2025-present)
timeline.note: Continuation of protectionist trade policies and immigration restrictions with traditional rights positions.

timeline.label: Leader of the Opposition (1975-1979)
timeline.note: Campaign for privatization energizes market reforms while advocating traditional social policy.

timeline.label: Prime Minister (1979-1990)
timeline.note: Privatization, union reforms, and strict immigration caps define the Thatcher government.

timeline.label: Montgomery Bus Boycott (1955-1956)
timeline.note: Economic boycotts foster mixed-market strategies while demanding full legal equality.

timeline.label: Poor People's Campaign (1967-1968)
timeline.note: Shift toward economic justice expands support for social programs without changing trade or rights stances.

timeline.label: Presidential Campaign (1964)
timeline.note: Campaign positions stress minimal regulation and traditional rights, with hawkish immigration stances.

timeline.label: Later Senate Career (1980s)
timeline.note: Becomes more libertarian on rights, supporting LGBTQ protections while keeping small-government economics.

timeline.label: First Lady & Activist (1933-1945)
timeline.note: Promotes social safety nets and civil rights while supporting selective trade agreements.

timeline.label: UN Human Rights Advocate (1945-1962)
timeline.note: Universal Declaration work cements commitment to full legal equality and humanitarian migration policies.

timeline.label: Senate Career (1953-1960)
timeline.note: Moderate on rights and immigration, maintaining selective trade and mixed economic policies.

timeline.label: Presidency (1961-1963)
timeline.note: Civil rights advocacy increases openness, while New Frontier keeps balanced economic approach.

timeline.label: Senate Majority Leader (1955-1960)
timeline.note: Builds consensus with moderate immigration and rights expansions, before Great Society agenda.

timeline.label: Great Society Era (1963-1968)
timeline.note: Medicare, Medicaid, and Voting Rights Act expand social programs and civil rights enforcement.

timeline.label: Vice Presidency (1953-1961)
timeline.note: Anti-communist trade protections and traditional rights positions dominate the Eisenhower era.

timeline.label: Presidency (1969-1974)
timeline.note: Opens China while imposing wage/price controls, shifts to more moderate rights stance.

timeline.label: House Minority Leader (1965-1973)
timeline.note: Supports selective immigration limits and traditional rights, with moderate economic policy.

timeline.label: Presidency (1974-1977)
timeline.note: Focus on healing post-Watergate sees slight moderation on rights while keeping market emphasis.

timeline.label: Vice Presidency (1981-1989)
timeline.note: Aligns with Reagan on deregulation and traditional rights while supporting selective immigration reforms.

timeline.label: Presidency (1989-1993)
timeline.note: Americans with Disabilities Act broadens rights protections even as economic policy stays market-focused.

timeline.label: Governor of Arkansas (1983-1992)
timeline.note: Education reforms and welfare adjustments signal centrist economics with moderate rights expansion.

timeline.label: First Term (1993-1996)
timeline.note: NAFTA passage and welfare reform balance free trade with moderate social programs.

timeline.label: Second Term (1997-2001)
timeline.note: Budget surpluses and expanded immigration quotas maintain centrist third-way approach.

timeline.label: Texas Governor (1995-2000)
timeline.note: Faith-based initiatives and tort reform underscore traditional rights with moderate economics.

timeline.label: First Term (2001-2004)
timeline.note: Post-9/11 security measures tighten immigration and civil liberties while cutting taxes.

timeline.label: Second Term (2005-2009)
timeline.note: Immigration reform attempts moderate stance while maintaining traditional rights positions.

timeline.label: Georgia Governor (1971-1975)
timeline.note: Civil rights advocacy and government efficiency reforms signal progressive social stance with fiscal moderation.

timeline.label: Presidency (1977-1981)
timeline.note: Human rights diplomacy and Refugee Act expand protections while deregulation begins in aviation and trucking.

timeline.label: Post-Presidency (1981-present)
timeline.note: Humanitarian work and LGBTQ advocacy shift toward more progressive positions on rights and immigration.

timeline.label: Academic Career (1950s-1970s)
timeline.note: Monetarism and free-market advocacy establish libertarian economic framework with civil liberties support.

timeline.label: Public Influence Era (1980s-2006)
timeline.note: Free to Choose advocacy promotes pure free markets, school vouchers, and opposition to licensing restrictions.

timeline.label: Academic Economics (1980s-1990s)
timeline.note: New trade theory supports free trade with moderate regulation and progressive social positions.

timeline.label: Public Commentary (2000-present)
timeline.note: Keynesian advocacy emphasizes fiscal stimulus, healthcare expansion, and strong social safety net.

timeline.label: Early Business Career (2000-2015)
timeline.note: Focus on innovation and disruption favors minimal regulation with moderate social positions.

timeline.label: Obama-Biden Era Alignment (2016-2020)
timeline.note: Support for carbon taxes, EV subsidies, and Biden vote reflect alignment with moderate Democratic positions.

timeline.label: Political Shift (2021-2024)
timeline.note: COVID policy criticism, free speech absolutism, and Republican alignment shift toward libertarian-conservative positions.

timeline.label: Investment Career (1960s-2000)
timeline.note: Value investing philosophy supports free markets with minimal regulation and moderate social positions.

timeline.label: Public Advocacy Era (2000-present)
timeline.note: Calls for higher taxes on wealthy and estate tax retention signal support for progressive taxation within capitalism.

timeline.label: Apple Founding & Early Years (1976-1985)
timeline.note: Counterculture roots balance entrepreneurial capitalism with socially liberal personal views.

timeline.label: Return to Apple (1997-2011)
timeline.note: Global supply chain strategy embraces free trade while maintaining progressive social stances.

timeline.label: Microsoft CEO (1975-2000)
timeline.note: Aggressive business strategy favors pure free markets with minimal regulation and libertarian-leaning rights.

timeline.label: Philanthropic Focus (2000-present)
timeline.note: Global health initiatives and education reform support increased public investment in social programs.

timeline.label: Amazon Growth Era (1994-2020)
timeline.note: E-commerce disruption and opposition to sales tax collection favor minimal market regulation.

timeline.label: Diversification & Advocacy (2020-present)
timeline.note: Space ventures and climate pledge maintain free-market approach with increased focus on environmental issues.

timeline.label: Academic Career (1905-1933)
timeline.note: Pacifist views and support for Weimar social democracy favor progressive economics and civil liberties.

timeline.label: American Exile (1933-1955)
timeline.note: Civil rights activism and democratic socialism advocacy emphasize social justice and nuclear disarmament.

timeline.label: Scientific Career (1890s-1934)
timeline.note: Focus on scientific research and education access supports progressive social programs and gender equality.

timeline.label: Polio Vaccine Development (1947-1955)
timeline.note: Decision not to patent vaccine reflects commitment to public health over profit maximization.

timeline.label: Later Career & Institute (1963-1995)
timeline.note: Continued advocacy for accessible healthcare and public research funding maintains progressive stance.

timeline.label: Academic & Public Science (1960s-1996)
timeline.note: Nuclear disarmament advocacy and science education support balanced public investment with civil liberties.

timeline.label: Research Career (1960-1990)
timeline.note: Conservation work emphasizes environmental protection with moderate economic interventions.

timeline.label: Global Advocacy (1990-present)
timeline.note: Climate activism and youth empowerment programs support stronger environmental regulations and social programs.

timeline.label: Anti-Apartheid Activism (1944-1990)
timeline.note: Armed resistance and socialist economic views support extensive redistribution and full legal equality.

timeline.label: Presidency (1994-1999)
timeline.note: Reconciliation approach balances market-friendly reforms with strong social programs and rights protections.

timeline.label: Liberal Party Era (1904-1924)
timeline.note: Social reforms and labor legislation balance market capitalism with welfare state beginnings.

timeline.label: World War II Leadership (1940-1945)
timeline.note: War economy and imperial defense drive protectionist policies and state controls.

timeline.label: Post-War PM (1951-1955)
timeline.note: Maintains welfare state while resisting nationalization and supporting Commonwealth immigration controls.

timeline.label: South African Activism (1893-1914)
timeline.note: Satyagraha development emphasizes self-sufficiency and civil rights within colonial framework.

timeline.label: Indian Independence Movement (1915-1948)
timeline.note: Swadeshi movement promotes local production and cottage industries with emphasis on social equality.

timeline.label: Early Industrial Era (1903-1920)
timeline.note: Mass production efficiency balanced with $5 workday reflects paternalistic capitalism.

timeline.label: Later Years (1920-1947)
timeline.note: Anti-union stance and isolationist views support protectionism with traditional social values.

timeline.label: Steel Industry Dominance (1870-1901)
timeline.note: Monopolistic practices and union suppression exemplify Gilded Age capitalism.

timeline.label: Philanthropic Era (1901-1919)
timeline.note: Gospel of Wealth philosophy supports voluntary redistribution through libraries and education.

timeline.label: Standard Oil Era (1870-1911)
timeline.note: Vertical integration and market control define pure free-market approach without government oversight.

timeline.label: Philanthropy & Legacy (1911-1937)
timeline.note: Foundation work in medicine and education softens public image while maintaining conservative values.

timeline.label: United Farm Workers Formation (1962-1975)
timeline.note: Grape boycotts and union organizing emphasize worker protections and fair labor practices.

timeline.label: Later Leadership (1975-1993)
timeline.note: Opposition to illegal immigration reflects concern for union wage standards while maintaining social justice focus.

timeline.label: Civil Rights Activism (1955-1970s)
timeline.note: Bus boycott and NAACP work exemplify nonviolent resistance for full legal equality.

timeline.label: Women's Suffrage Movement (1852-1906)
timeline.note: Voting rights advocacy and labor reform support progressive social programs with emphasis on equality.

timeline.label: ACLU Advocacy (1970s)
timeline.note: Gender equality litigation establishes legal framework for reproductive rights and civil liberties.

timeline.label: Supreme Court (1993-2020)
timeline.note: Consistent liberal voting record supports abortion rights, immigration protections, and economic regulation.

timeline.label: Supreme Court (1986-2016)
timeline.note: Originalist interpretation supports deregulation, states' rights on abortion, and traditional rights definitions.

timeline.label: NAACP Legal Defense (1940-1961)
timeline.note: Brown v. Board victory and civil rights litigation establish legal framework for desegregation.

timeline.label: Supreme Court (1967-1991)
timeline.note: Liberal voting record consistently supports social programs, civil rights expansion, and criminal justice reform.

timeline.label: Mayor of Burlington (1981-1989)
timeline.note: Municipal socialism and affordable housing initiatives establish progressive economic platform.

timeline.label: House & Senate Career (1991-2015)
timeline.note: Opposition to NAFTA and support for single-payer healthcare solidify democratic socialist positions.

timeline.label: Presidential Campaigns (2016-2020)
timeline.note: Medicare for All and wealth tax proposals advance social democratic economic platform.

timeline.label: Literary & Philosophical Career (1943-1982)
timeline.note: Objectivist philosophy advocates pure laissez-faire capitalism with minimal state and individual rights primacy.

timeline.label: Anti-War Activism (1960s-1970s)
timeline.note: Vietnam War opposition and critique of U.S. foreign policy establish libertarian socialist framework.

timeline.label: Media Criticism Era (1980s-present)
timeline.note: Manufacturing Consent analysis supports anarcho-syndicalist economics with radical immigration openness.

timeline.label: Early Papacy (1978-1989)
timeline.note: Anti-communist solidarity with Poland balances distributist economics and absolute pro-life positions.

timeline.label: Post-Cold War (1989-2005)
timeline.note: Critique of capitalism and consumerism maintains social teaching while opposing abortion and LGBTQ rights.

timeline.label: Early Chancellorship (2005-2011)
timeline.note: Labor market reforms and fiscal conservatism balance Christian democratic social market approach.

timeline.label: Refugee Crisis Era (2015-2021)
timeline.note: Open-door refugee policy shifts immigration stance while maintaining balanced economic approach.

timeline.label: First Presidential Terms (2000-2008)
timeline.note: Resource nationalism and centralized control establish state capitalism with conservative social policy.

timeline.label: Return to Power (2012-present)
timeline.note: Increased protectionism and anti-LGBTQ legislation shift toward more authoritarian nationalism.

timeline.label: Early Leadership (2012-2017)
timeline.note: Anti-corruption campaign and state enterprise strengthening consolidate party control over economy.

timeline.label: Consolidation Era (2018-present)
timeline.note: Common prosperity initiative and tech crackdown increase state ownership with nationalist immigration controls.

timeline.label: Nation Building (1959-1990)
timeline.note: Authoritarian developmentalism combines free-market policies with strict social controls and limited migration.

timeline.label: Senior Minister (1990-2015)
timeline.note: Asian values advocacy maintains model of market capitalism with restricted civil liberties.
